quote: Excuse me...
You're Doctor Bashir, aren't you?
That's right.
I'm Leeta.  I've been meaning to    come by the Infirmary to see you.
Oh, dear... how long have you had    this cough?
A few days now...
May I?
Cough for me...
Hmm...
Is it serious, Doctor?
No... but it's a good thing you came    to me when you did...
We need to start your treatment right    away.       Can I have a Fanalian toddy, very    hot.
Make that two...       I've been feeling a bit of a cough    coming on myself...
I'm sorry to hear that, Doctor.
Please... call me --
Julian.
Hi...
I'm Jadzia...
Leeta...
Before I forget, here's the    immunological data you asked for...
How sweet of you to put this together    for me so quickly...
I think I'll go look it over right    now...
Oh, by the way... I just heard the    Lexington is going to be docking    here for a few days...
The Lexington... ?
Excuse me for just one second.
Jadzia...
Do you happen to know when the    Lexington is coming?
Three weeks.       Don't you have a friend aboard?
Do I... ?
The medical officer... Elizabeth    Lense...
(as if trying to     remember)   Elizabeth Lense... I think she may    have been in my class at Starfleet    Medical.
Wasn't she the valedictorian?
That's right...
And you were... salutatorian?
Second in my class...       If I hadn't mistaken a pre-ganglionic    fiber --
For a post-ganglionic nerve, I know.
(trying to shrug it     off)   I would've been valedictorian.
Oh, well...       You must really be looking forward    to seeing her...
I can hardly wait.       I'd better get back to Leeta...
Julian... ?       That way.
Jake!
Hey, Dad.
What's this?
I just thought it was time for a    change...       What do you think?
I like it.       How was Bajor?
Beautiful, you should've come with    me.
The re-opening of some old Library    isn't exactly my idea of a good time.

This wasn't just any old Library...    we're talking about the most extensive    collection of Bajoran antiquities on    the planet.  I saw manuscripts that    date back to before the Fall of the    First Republic.
Great...
Look at this...
What is it, some kind of ship?
According to legend, the ancient    Bajorans used ships like these to    explore their star system... eight    hundred years ago...
You mean that when humans were first    sailing across the oceans, Bajorans    were already going to other planets?
Some scholars think they made it all    the way to Cardassia...
Seems hard to believe... what are    these?
Solar sails... these ships were    propelled by light pressure...
Like a sailboat catching the wind...
Exactly...
I wonder if a ship like this could    really fly... ?
I don't know... that's why I'm going    to build one...
-- I'm expecting a lumber shipment    from Bajor this afternoon.
(struck by this odd     request)   Okay...
Which reminds me... I'll also need a    saber saw.
A saber saw?
You know... to cut wood.
Why not use a laser cutter?
Because I want to use the same types    of tools the Bajorans had.
This should do fine, Major... As    soon as these cargo containers are    out of the way, I'll start    construction.
Sir, I've looked over the    specifications you brought back from    Bajor...
... I'm not sure the design is    spaceworthy, and I'm positive a ship    like this couldn't have made it from    Bajor to Cardassia.
Why do you say that?

At sublight speeds, the trip would've    taken them years, and that's assuming    ideal conditions.  One unexpected    ion storm in the Denorias Belt    would've torn the sails to pieces    and left them stranded.
Well maybe they were lucky and didn't    run into any storms.

I just don't see how a ship like    this could've made the trip.  They    didn't even have replicators back    then... they would've had to store    their air supply...       -- and there's only enough room     onboard for a few weeks worth.
Maybe they recycled it somehow...    using some kind of photosynthetic    plant.
Maybe...
You sound like a Cardassian...
I beg your pardon?
They've denied the possibility of    ancient contact for decades because    they can't stand the idea that Bajor    had interstellar flight before they    did.
With all due respect, Major... you're    beginning to sound like a Romulan.
A Romulan?
There's no piece of technology in    existence that they don't claim they    invented before everyone else...
Look... I'm not planning to spend    the next few years sailing to    Cardassia... I just want to build    one of these ships and prove that    it's spaceworthy...
A computer model could do that...    why go to all the trouble?
Why?       Because it'll be fun...

I've been thinking... according to    the star charts, the most difficult    part of the trip between Bajor and    Cardassia would be getting through    the Denorias Belt.  After that, it    would be smooth sailing the rest of    the way.
Really...
Just being able to make that part of    the trip would go a long way toward    demonstrating that the Bajorans could    have made the journey to Cardassia.
Seems reasonable...
It would only take about... four,    five days...
That's not so long...
So...
What?
What do you say you come with me?     We'll have a great time.  The ship'll    be ready to go in another week.
I don't know, Dad... Nog's birthday    is next week... I promised I'd do    something with him.
All right.  We can do it after his    birthday.
That's when Leanne is supposed to    get back from Bajor.  I really want    to see her, and I don't know how    long she's going to be here.
Oh... well... if you can't do it,    you can't do it.
I'd like to, but... it's just not    good timing, you know?
Sure.  I understand.
A survey of Cygnian Respiratory    diseases...       Fascinating...

I'm reading everything I can get my    hands on so I won't be caught flat-   footed by the intrepid Doctor Lense.     It's useless, of course... she's    probably discovered the cure to aging    by now...
I take it the two of you were...    competitive.

Absolutely.  We were neck and neck    right up to the final exam.  And    then I blew it.       And that's how she wound up on the    Lexington.  A post virtually everyone    in our graduating class was hoping    for.
Including you?
No, this is the assignment I wanted.
Then what does it matter?
Don't you see?  She could've had    this post, she could've taken it    from me.  Somehow... no matter what    I accomplish while I'm here, that'll    always make me feel... second best...
Hi...
Come on in...
I brought you something to eat...
Thanks... let me just finish welding    this and I'll take a break.
Benjamin... I can't believe the work    you've put into this...
I'm just following the blueprints...
(touching a carved     surface)   But you didn't have to bother with    detail like this to prove the ship    is spaceworthy.
I suppose not... but I want everything    to be just right... it's an exact    replica...       Except for the gravity net I installed    in the floor... weightlessness makes    me queasy...
I haven't seen you like this in a    long time...
Like what?
So caught up in something... so    excited...       Not since... not since you and    Jennifer decided to have a baby.
The nursery...
I don't think anyone's ever put more    effort into making a room for their    baby...
But you have to admit it turned out    pretty well...
Especially the starscape on the    ceiling...
Jake loved that ceiling... when we    moved out of the house, he couldn't    understand why we couldn't bring it    with us.
You're disappointed he's not going    with you on this trip, Aren't you?
He's got other things he'd rather be    doing, friends he'd rather spend    time with.
It's funny... a year or two ago,    nothing would've stopped him from    coming with me on an adventure like    this.       I guess I waited too long...
You'll have other adventures together,    Benjamin... they'll just be different.     Believe me, I know.  I've been a    father a couple of times, myself.       I could tell you stories...
You already have...
That's right... I have, haven't I?       Then you know I'm right.
Computer...
Are there any messages for me?
One... a communication from    Wellington, New Zealand.
Display it on screen...
Jake...
Hey, Dad...
So what do you think?
It's terrific... maybe a little small    for two people... but I think I could    get used to it.
That is, if you still want me along.
I'm expecting a report from Starfleet    Command.  You'd better relay it to    me aboard the Baraka as soon as it    comes in.
The Baraka... ?
That's what I named the ship... it's    Swahili for "good fortune"...
Benjamin, there's an incoming message    from Gul Dukat... he says it's urgent    he speak with you.
(gesturing to his     office)   Patch it through to my office...
I understand you're planning a trip.
Word gets around.
I can't believe that a man of your    intelligence would take stock in    Bajoran fairy tales about ancient    contact.
If you recall, you thought the    Celestial Temple was a Bajoran fairy    tale...       -- until we discovered the wormhole.
I suggest you reconsider your plans;    solar vessels are very fragile, and    it's a long way to the Denorias Belt    at sublight speeds...
Don't worry.  I'll have emergency    equipment aboard.  If something goes    wrong, Major Kira can get a runabout    to me within an hour.
An hour can be a long time...    especially if you happen to encounter    something unexpected.
Like what?
Oh, I don't know.  A Maquis ship,    perhaps...
Why would the Maquis have any quarrel    with an unarmed ship sailing toward    the Denorias Belt... they have nothing    at stake here, nothing to prove...    or should I say, disprove.
Commander, I contacted you out of    concern for your safety, but you    seem to be intimating that I've made    some sort of threat.
I'm glad I was wrong.  For a moment    there I thought you'd been put in    charge of the Cardassian Ministry    for the Refutation of Bajoran    Fairy Tales...
Since I don't seem to have dissuaded    you from undertaking this little    voyage of yours, I'll wish you luck    instead.  Let's hope you don't need    it.
All right... first we've got to deploy    the mainsails.       I want you to take that winch over    there...
When I tell you, start cranking with    all you've got...
Let's do it...
Keep at it, nice and steady...
That's as far as it'll go...
Okay...    (indicating another     winch)   I'll work on the spritsails while    you deploy the jib...
Put your back into it...
That's it... we'll make a sailor out    of you, yet...
Now I get it...
What?
Why you wanted to build this ship.
Jake, trim the starboard sprit by    about six degrees...
O.K.  How's that?
That should do it... we'll start    picking up speed as the pressure on    the sails builds...
Hey, Dad... where do we sleep?
There are hammocks we can string up    later...
This is the bathroom?
It was designed for a zero-gravity    environment...
How do you...
You'll get the hang of it...
We'll be tacking against the light    most of the way... we'll run like    this for the next ninety minutes or    so... then we'll come about and I'll    calculate our next leg...
How about something to drink... ?
Don't tell me we only have zero-   gravity rations...
That's all the ancient Bajorans had...
Listen...
I don't hear anything...
Exactly... not even the hum of an    engine...

It's almost like being on the deck    of an old sailing ship... except the    stars aren't just up in the sky,    they're all around us...       Imagine what the ancient Bajorans    must've felt... heading out into    space in ships like this one... not    knowing what they would find... or    who they would meet.
Jake... I know you didn't really    want to come on this trip...
I just want to say I'm glad you're    here...
Dad... there's something I need to    talk to you about...
Sure, what is it?
First you should read this...
It's a story I wrote...
A story...       -- so that's why you kept putting    this away every time I walked into    the room...
If you keep an eye on the rigging,    I'll read it right now...
Deal...
It looked better where it was    before...
I thought you might want to know    that the Lexington docked a few    minutes ago...
Already... ?  I thought it wasn't    coming for another day or two...
She's at Quark's...
Are you going to go talk to her or    not?
She's busy...
You never mentioned she was    beautiful...
I never mentioned her at all, not to    you anyway.
Morn gave me three-to-one odds that    you'll exchange awkward pleasantries    for a few minutes and say goodbye...
(with a wink and a     nudge)   I'm betting that your charm will    take you further...
She's getting up...
So... what do you think... ?
I liked it...
You're not just saying that?
No... it's good...
What did you think about the part    where Jared thinks he's been betrayed?
I'm not sure he'd confront Iko about    it... at least not right away.
Yeah... I guess he could wait until    after he gets back from the    Demilitarized Zone.
That'd be more believable.
So you really think it was good,    huh?
I think it shows a lot of promise.
Promise... ?
In a few places you're writing about    things you haven't actually    experienced.  At least... I hope you    haven't experienced.  Unless you've    joined the Maquis without telling    me.
I can't talk about it...
I had you going there...
I'm impressed, Jake, I really am...    You should keep writing.
I'm thinking about it.
Don't think about it, do it.
What I mean is... yesterday I got a    communication from the Pennington    School in New Zealand... they offered    me a writing fellowship...
That's terrific, Jake... I... didn't    even know you'd applied...
I didn't really.  What happened is,    I showed a story I wrote to Mrs.    O'Brien... I guess she liked it    because she showed it to a friend of    hers who knows someone at the school    and --
A mast support gave way... the    starboard sprit is fouling one of    the mainsails...
Can we fix it... ?
I don't think so... we're going to    have to jettison the sprit...
Let's fall off a little... take some    pressure off the sails...
Lock it down and give me a hand...
One more turn...
Good work...
All right... I'm going to jettison    the sprit...
That's better... but it looks like    we're getting a lot of spill off the    sails... we won't make as much headway    on each tack...
I don't know if we'll be able to get    to the Denorias Belt like this.
The ancient Bajorans probably ran    into these kinds of problems, too.
I suppose they did.
Did they give up and go home?
Seems to me we're here to prove they    didn't.
Then what are we waiting for?
Let's get to work.
Coming about...

Bring me my bow, of burn - ing   gold...   Bring me my ar - rows of    de - sire...   Bring me my spear!  O clouds ?   un-fold...   Bring me my cha - ri-ots of fire!   I will not cease, from men-tal    fight...   Nor shall my sword sleep in    hand...   Till we have built,    Je-ru - sa - lem...
That was beautiful, Chief... just    beautiful.  You know what we should    do... ?
What?
Go to Quark's... and sing it for    everyone there...
Maybe we should switch to synthale...
No... this isn't a synthale kind of    night...       She walked right by me, Chief.  Acted    like I wasn't even there.
You know what I think... I think    she's in love with you...
I don't think so.
It's the only explanation.       Unless of course, she ignored you    because she can't stand you.
Isn't there an explanation somewhere    in between?
You're not an in-between kind of    guy.
What do you mean?
People either love you or hate you.
Really?
I hated you when we first met.
I remember.
But now...
But now... ?
Now...    (can't quite bring     himself to say it)   I don't.
That means a lot to me, Chief, it    really does...
That's from the heart, too... I really    do...       -- not hate you anymore...
If you want to find out why she    ignored you, you're going to have to    confront her.
You're right...       I'm going to go up to her and ask    her flat out where she gets off    walking past me like that.
Better wait until tomorrow...
Why should I?  Why not right now?
Because right now you can barely    stand up.
Good point.
And did those feet in an-cient    time...   Walk up-on Eng-land's moun-tains    green?
And was the Ho - ly Lamb of    God...   On Eng-land's plea-sant    pas - tures seen?
This'll be the last time we have to    come about for a while...
Good.
Ready... ?       Now...
Nice job.  Come on...
Let's set up the hammock and take a    break...
Hop in...
Not bad...
So, I suppose congratulations are in    order.  Pennington's a good school...    very competitive...
Dad, before you say anything... I'm    turning down the Fellowship...
Turning it down... why?
I'm just... not ready to go.
Jake, an opportunity like this doesn't    come along every day...
I can defer admission for a year.     If I want to go then, I still can.
That's great, but... why would things    be any different in a year?
I don't know... they just might be,    that's all.

You know... I wasn't much older than    you are when I left for San Francisco    to go to Starfleet Academy.  For the    first few days, I was so homesick I    went back to my house in New Orleans    every night for dinner.
I'd materialize in the living room    at six-thirty and take my seat at    the table like I'd just come down    the stairs...
You must've used up a month's worth    of Transporter Credits...

My parents... they never said anything    about it... just "How you doing,    son, how was school today?" They    knew I'd get over being homesick    soon enough, and they were right.     By the third or fourth day, you    couldn't have pried me away from the    campus.
Of course... if you go to Pennington,    you won't be able to beam back to    the station to have dinner with your    old man, but after a week or so,    you'll get over it...
Dad, it's not me I'm worried about...    it's you.
Me?
If I go, you'll be all alone...

Jake, I appreciate you thinking about    me... but don't turn down this    opportunity on my account.  I'll    have plenty of people to keep me    company.  I can have dinner with    Dax, or Doctor Bashir... even Quark.
I guess... but I'd feel a lot better    if... you had someone... you know...    someone special... like a    girlfriend...
I see...
The thing is... you haven't had a    date in over a year.  A year, Dad...
I guess I've been too busy...
You've got to make time for these    things...
You're right...
I can't believe this... I'm getting    advice about women from my son...
Don't think of me as your son right    now.  Just think of me as another    guy.       Another guy who happens to know a    very attractive lady who wants to    meet you.
Are you trying to set me up?
Why not?
What was that... ?
I'm not sure... but whatever hit us    almost tore off the port mainsail...
Main power is off-line.  We're moving    at warp...
How can that be... ?
I don't know...
What happened... ?
Good question...
There's no record of any spatial    anomalies in this region...
What are these... ?
Tachyon eddies... they run all through    this area...
Could we have gotten caught up in    one... ?
No... tachyons don't have enough    mass to affect a ship of this...
What is it?
But this isn't any ordinary ship, it    has a lot more surface area relative    to its mass...
Because of the sails...
And since tachyons travel faster    than light, it could be that their    impact on the sails somehow    accelerated us up to warp speeds...       We could be light years off course...
The question is, where did we end    up?
You check the rigging, I'll try to    figure that out...
We lost the jib and port mainsail...
Damn...
What?
It's useless...
There's no way for us to figure out    where we are... or where we're    going...
We'd better contact the station, let    them know they're going to have to    come get us...
We were so close... another day and    we would've reached the Denorias    Belt.
Hey, we did pretty well making it as    far as we did...
Is something wrong?
The station's not responding...
Is the com unit damaged?
Not as far as I can see...
Maybe they haven't received the    message yet...
Do you think we could have been    carried that far away from the    station... ?
I suppose it's possible...
They'll find us eventually... right?
Sure...
Excuse me...
Yes... ?
We went to medical school together.     I'm Julian Bashir.
You're Bashir... ?
You seem surprised...
I... thought you were Andorian...
What... ?
Someone pointed out an Andorian to    me at a party and said he was Julian    Bashir.  It was New Year's Eve... at    Bruce Lucier's, four years ago.
I went to that party.  With my friend    Erib... he's Andorian.
I must've gotten you mixed up... all    these years, I thought you were    someone else.
Didn't you see me give my speech at    graduation?
No, I was backstage waiting to give    my speech.  I was so nervous I almost    passed out.
I know what you mean...
So... you gave me quite a run for my    money.       If it hadn't been for that pre-   ganglionic fiber...
You know about that?
I know that if you hadn't gotten it    wrong you would've been valedictorian.
I never got a chance to congratulate    you...
Seems like a long time ago, doesn't    it... ?

Not so long...       So... you got the Lexington... you    must've had quite an adventure out    there... exploring uncharted space,    meeting fascinating new races with    fascinating new diseases...

Actually, it ended up being more of    a charting expedition.  Sometimes it    would be months between planetary    systems.  You wouldn't believe how    excited I'd get if we actually found    something living -- even if it was    just some moss under a rock.
Don't take this the wrong way... but    there were times when I regretted    not taking your assignment.
Really... ?
I read your paper on the immuno-   therapy project you've been doing on    Bajor.  It was brilliant.
Thank you...
I really envy the opportunity you    have to work on that kind of long-   term project.  On the Lexington, it    was collect your samples and then on    to the next system.
I suppose I am lucky at that...
So what's happening on Bajor?  Were    you able to get the T-cell anomalies    under control...
If you're really interested, why    don't we go to the Infirmary and I    can show you my latest results?
I'd love to...
Morn...
About that bet.  I believe the odds    were three to one.
So, dad... we're not going to run    out of air or anything, are we?
Don't worry.  Someone'll find us    before that happens.
Why don't you tell me about this    woman you want me to meet?
Well, she's a freighter captain.
(not sure if he likes     this)   A freighter captain?
Dad, trust me... you'll like her.
All right, I'll meet her... on one    condition...
What?
That you won't base your decision    about going to Pennington on how our    date turns out...
Don't worry... I won't.  I've already    decided to wait at least a year.
How come?
I've heard that you can only write    about what you've experienced... and    you've got to admit, Deep Space Nine    is a pretty good place to get    experience.
Dad...
We've got company...
What do you think they want... ?
Looks like we're about to find out...
What can I do for you, Dukat?
Let me be the first to congratulate    you, Commander...
Congratulate me?
For managing to get all the way    here...
All the way where?
Don't you know?  You've just entered    the Cardassian system...
The tachyon eddy... it must've taken    us past the Denorias Belt and brought    us here...
The same thing must've happened to    the ancient Bajorans...
We did it... we proved the trip was    possible...
I hate to interrupt your celebration,    but I've been asked to convey a    message from the Cardassian    Government...

"Your voyage is a testament to the    spirit of the ancient Bajorans who    first ventured out into space... it    could not be more appropriate that    your arrival coincides with the    discovery here on Cardassia of an    ancient crash site... "
"A site that our archaeologists believe    contains the remnants of one of the    Bajoran vessels whose journey you    have just recreated... "
What an amazing coincidence...
Yes...
Welcome...
